abstract.p: Ken Weber letter holds May 10 article on newsletters that follow Fidelity funds erred in focusing on short-term results

block.p: ''Judging the Many Newsletters That Judge Fidelity's Funds'' (Investing It, May 10) made a mistake that financial experts warn against -- it focused on short-term results. One 12-month period offers virtually no clue as to consistent long-term performance.

''Judging the Many Newsletters That Judge Fidelity's Funds'' (Investing It, May 10) made a mistake that financial experts warn against -- it focused on short-term results. One 12-month period offers virtually no clue as to consistent long-term performance.

Readers should know about the outstanding long-term records of two of the newsletters cited. Hulbert Financial Digest, the source of your statistics, ranks Fidelity Monitor first among all investment newsletters for its risk-adjusted performance over the eight years ended March 31, and in second place for the 10-year period. (Jack Bowers, the editor, is my firm's chief investment strategist.) Fidelity Insight is ranked fifth and first for the respective periods.
These excellent newsletters are ahead of the pack in a crowded field.
KEN WEBER Lake Success, N.Y., May 11
The writer is the president of Weber Asset Management Inc.
